articles.description:
STOCKHOLM, May 12 (IPS) - An entirely unnecessary and all too tangible nightmare continues to scourge Ukraine. Without doubt, one catastrophe after another still awaits. Much of Ukraine’s harvest, of paramount importance to global food supply, is at risk of being lost due to Vladimir Putin’s and the Russian army’s belligerent actions. Last year, Ukraine harvested a record of 106 million tonnes of grain – 25, or even 50 percent of this amount is currently feared to be lost during this year while most experts add that “this is an optimistic forecast.”

Read the full story, “War and Famines Warnings of Potential Outcomes of the War in Ukraine”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: War and Famines  Warnings of Potential Outcomes of the War in Ukraine

articles.description:
ROME, May 12 (IPS) - The writer is Director, Global Health Justice Program, Society for International Development (SID), and Co-chair Geneva Global Health Hub (G2H2). In what has been defined a historic consensus decision aimed at protecting the world from future infectious diseases crises, on 1st December 2021, the special session of the World Health Assembly agreed to kickstart a global process to draft and negotiate a convention, agreement or other international instrument to strengthen pandemic prevention, preparedness and response.

Read the full story, “Projections for a Pandemic Future: in Whose Interest?”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Projections for a Pandemic Future: in Whose Interest?

articles.description:

articles.description:
May 11 (IPS) - The past 20 years have seen a significant decline in maternal mortality rates from 342 deaths to 211 per 100,000 globally . But every day, more than 800 women around the world die from complications of pregnancy and childbirth, up to 42 days after delivery. Most of these deaths are preventable.

Read the full story, “Most Maternal Deaths Are Preventable: How To Improve Outcomes in South Africa”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Most Maternal Deaths Are Preventable: How To Improve Outcomes in South Africa

articles.description: If the thought of retiring your comfortable sweats and choosing a new outfit to leave the house in each morning is an intimidating prospect, you're in good company. For the better part of the pandemic, I've lived in a pair of stretchy, soft wool trousers in the cooler months, switching allegiance in summer to a white linen dress that my brother-in-law dubbed "the ghost dress" (likening its so flowy, so oversized shape to that of a large bedsheet with a hole cut out for my head).
articles.title: Style Guide: How to dress for the office

articles.description: Finnish President Sauli Niinisto and Prime Minister Sanna Marin took the first step toward a formal NATO application.

articles.description: Finnish President Sauli Niinisto and Prime Minister Sanna Marin took the first step toward a formal NATO application.

articles.author: Annabelle Timsit
articles.description: “Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has altered the European and Finnish security environment," Foreign Minister Pekka Haavisto told Parliament.
articles.title: Finland’s leaders seek to join NATO ‘without delay,’ after Ukraine invasion

articles.author: Theodora Yu
articles.description: Cardinal Joseph Zen, who was once bishop of Hong Kong, is one of the most prominent pro-democracy activists from the Catholic Church.
articles.title: Hong Kong arrests 90-year-old cardinal on foreign collusion charges

articles.description: Cardinal Joseph Zen, who was once bishop of Hong Kong, is one of the most prominent pro-democracy activists from the Catholic Church.

articles.author: Associated Press
articles.description: Qatar’s emir has arrived in Iran for talks with the Iranian president, state media reported, as efforts to save Tehran’s tattered nuclear deal with world powers hit a deadlock
articles.title: Qatari emir in Iran for talks amid tensions over nuke deal

articles.author: Omar Faruk | AP
articles.description: Somalia is set to hold its long-delayed presidential vote on Sunday, ending the convoluted electoral process that raised tensions in the country when the president’s term expired last year without a successor in place
articles.title: Somalia set to elect new president amid growing insecurity

articles.author: Kim Tong-Hyung and Hyung-Jin Kim | AP
articles.description: North Korea has imposed a nationwide lockdown to control its first acknowledged COVID-19 outbreak of the pandemic
articles.title: North Korea confirms 1st COVID outbreak, Kim orders lockdown

articles.author: Rachel Pannett
articles.description: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said his plan was intended to cut illegal sea crossings, but Ukrainians fleeing war could be included by default.
articles.title: U.K. law could send Ukrainian refugees who enter via Ireland to Rwanda

articles.author: Associated Press
articles.description: Israel’s military has demolished 18 buildings and structures in the occupied West Bank following a Supreme Court decision that would force around 1,000 Palestinians out of an area declared a firing zone
articles.title: Israel levels Palestinian homes ahead of settlement approval

articles.author: Associated Press
articles.description: The Palestinian Authority has rejected an Israeli request to hold a joint investigation into the deadly shooting of Al Jazeera journalist Shireen Abu Akleh
articles.title: Palestinians reject probe with Israel of reporter's killing

articles.author: Isabel Debre | AP
articles.description: Iran is scheduled to put to death a 50-year-old Swedish-Iranian physician within nine days
articles.title: EXPLAINER: Who's the Swedish doctor facing execution in Iran

articles.author: William Booth
articles.description: The biggest expansion in decades promises to transform the city for commuters and visitors.
articles.title: Elizabeth line: London unveils its new Tube line, 10 stories underground

articles.author: Michelle Ye Hee Lee
articles.description: North Korea says it has detected the omicron variant in its capital, the first time the country has admitted to a positive case since the pandemic began more than two years ago.
articles.title: North Korea admits to coronavirus outbreak for the first time

articles.author: Anthony Faiola
articles.description: From deep within the steel plant, a Ukrainian soldier facing death issues a plea to the world: "A lot of people gave up their lives. Don’t waste this sacrifice.”
articles.title: Inside Mariupol’s besieged steel plant, a symbol of bravery and terror

articles.author: Adam Taylor
articles.description: The pandemic didn't go away, but global attention may be elsewhere.
articles.title: Remember covid? Ukraine war, inflation upstage global virus summit.

articles.author: Edith M. Lederer | AP
articles.description: The United States has clashed with China and Russia over their strong opposition to the U.S. push for new U.N. sanctions on North Korea over its missile and nuclear programs
articles.title: US clashes with China and Russia over North Korea sanctions

articles.author: Sonia PÉrez D. | AP
articles.description: A Guatemala judge who last week ordered nine former police and military officers to stand trial for alleged crimes during that country’s civil war, says that death threats against him had increased since announcing his decision
articles.title: Guatemala judge threatened after decision on civil war crime

articles.author: Sammy Westfall
articles.description: His father was a dictator. But Marcos's victory at the polls should not come as a surprise.
articles.title: Philippine election: How did Marcos win the presidency?

articles.author: Rick Noack
articles.description: The Ukraine men's national soccer team is scheduled to play in a World Cup qualifying playoff match in June.
articles.title: In a soccer friendly, German fans cheer on a loss to Ukraine

articles.author: Edith M. Lederer | AP
articles.description: The top international official in Bosnia is warning that Bosnian Serbs are trying to “secede” and undermine the country’s sovereignty
articles.title: Top global official: Bosnian Serbs are trying to `secede'

articles.author: Emily Langer
articles.description: The onetime Communist apparatchik became a central figure in the dissolution of the Soviet Union and agreed to relinquish his country’s nuclear weapons in the aftermath of the Cold War.
articles.title: Leonid Kravchuk, first president of independent Ukraine, dies at 88

articles.author: Samantha Schmidt
articles.description: Authorities believe the brazen killing of Paraguayan prosecutor Marcelo Pecci at a resort in Colombia was related to his work investigating “international terrorism.”
articles.title: Prosecutor on his honeymoon is gunned down by hit men at beach

articles.author: Rachel Pannett
articles.description: The Senate is expected to vote in the coming days on an aid package for Ukraine that the House overwhelmingly approved Tuesday night.
articles.title: Finland’s president to address NATO membership; E.U. fails to agree on Russian oil embargo

articles.author: Shane Harris
articles.description: The Biden administration has drawn up guidance around intelligence-sharing with Ukraine that is calibrated to avoid heightening tensions between Washington and Moscow.
articles.title: Intelligence-sharing with Ukraine designed to prevent wider war

articles.author: Erin Cunningham
articles.description: Russia's use of banned cluster weapons has caused hundreds of civilian casualties in Ukraine, according to a new report from Human Rights Watch.
articles.title: Russia’s use of cluster munitions causing ‘intense’ harm in Ukraine

articles.author: Derek Gatopoulos | AP
articles.description: The remote Greek island of Tilos has pioneered a recycling plant that could act as a blueprint for other islands — including popular holiday destinations — that struggle with waste disposal
articles.title: Battery-powered Greek island bets on green future

articles.author: Jeanne Whalen
articles.description: U.S.-led sanctions are depriving Russia of technology, forcing it to use computer chips meant for refrigerators and dishwashers in some military equipment, Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo said.
articles.title: Sanctions forcing Russia to use appliance parts in military gear, U.S. says

articles.author: Karen DeYoung
articles.description: In a potential embarrassment for his administration, a growing number of hemispheric leaders have said they will not attend an Americas summit, to be hosted by President Biden next month in Los Angeles, if the meeting excludes Cuba, Venezuela and Nicaragua.
articles.title: Biden-hosted Americas summit facing boycott over invitation list

articles.author: Michael Birnbaum
articles.description: They’re forced into “filtration camps” to face strip searches and harsh questioning.
articles.title: Ukrainian refugees in Russia report interrogations, detention and other abuses

articles.author: Ellen Francis
articles.description: Ukraine’s prosecutor general said 21-year-old Vadim Shishimarin would stand trial in the killing of an unarmed resident in the Sumy region.
articles.title: Ukraine announces first war crimes trial of Russian soldier in custody

articles.author: Isabelle Khurshudyan
articles.description: In towns near Kharkiv, police dodge mines and booby traps to document Russian war crimes.
articles.title: Ukraine regains territory, and crime scene investigators move in
